newsitem.title: USA: Kmart looks for improved second half.
newsitem.headline: Kmart looks for improved second half.

text.p: Kmart Corp. Wednesday reported a profit for the second quarter as the struggling retailer's sales improved and costs declined.

Kmart posted net income from continuing operations of $34 million, or 7 cents per share, in the quarter ended July 31, compared with a loss of $54 million, or 12 cents a share, in the year-ago period.
The 1995 results included a loss from discontinued operations of $76 million.

Total sales for the Troy, Mich.-based company's 2,143 Kmart stores and 168 Builders Square retail outlets edged down 1.5 percent to $8.31 billion from $8.44 billion. Total comparable store sales rose 1.6 percent.
Comparable sales for U.S. Kmart stores increased 2.2 percent for the quarter, and 2.9 percent for the first six months of 1996, both below Kmart's expectations.
Kmart operates 134 stores in international markets.
The retailer's gross margin dropped to 21.7 percent of sales from 22.5 percent, as Kmart marked down prices to clear seasonal and discontinued merchandise and sold its auto service business.
Selling, general and administrative expenses fell by $117 million for the quarter.
The second-quarter results reflected weak performance at Kmart's Canadian operation, the company said.
Kmart said it expected sales of appliances and consumer electronics, as well as apparel and linens, to improve in the second half of the year.
During the second quarter, Kmart completed $4.7 billion in new financing through a three-year $3.7 billion credit facility and a $1 billion public offering of convertible preferred securities.
Kmart's stock rose 25 cents to $10.75 on the New York Stock Exchange at mid-morning.
